Overall rating: 9/10  By far my favourite city-building sim of all time.  I actually bought this game because I had heard a ♥♥♥♥-tonne of ♥♥♥♥ about how awful the new Simcity was, and I was really craving a Simcity-like game. After playing Tropico, I don't think I could go back to playing Simcity ever again.   Tropico is more or less what Simcity would be if it had a nonsensical, but fantastically humorous storyline. You play as El Presidente, ruler of some island, and the game takes you through a bunch of different and ridiculous scenarios. Describing them would spoil the fun of you finding them out on their own. In the meantime, you have to keep everyone happy - be it the religious group, the nationalists or the environmentalists, which often requires a delicate balance in where you spend your hard-earned dollars.  As for the gameplay, the learning curve is just about where you want it to be. You have a lot of leeway in the earlier missions and the objectives are relatively straightforward, whilst the later objectives can be a little frustrating and even unfair. There was one mission in particular where after playing for hours and completing the initial objectives, I was told that the next objective had to be completed by a certain date - this date had already passed, and I instantly failed the objective. I was... miserable, to say the least.  Unfortunately (or fortunately, depending on who you are), once you get the hang of the game and know what you're doing, things become a little bit too easy. Without trying to spoil anything, I'll just say that some forms of income are much easier to obtain than other forms, which creates somewhat of a conundrum - you WANT to diversify your city because it's more fun that way, but it requires more work for it to be successful.   The graphics are pretty standard for a modern game, although the Caribbean-inspired music was stuck in my head for quite some time.   Overall, I'd most definitely recommend this game for anyone that likes city-building simulation games (be it Sim City, Rollercoaster Tycoon, Theme Park, etc).

Tropico 4 is a fun way to casually waste away tens or even hundreds of hours, at minimum. If you're already familiar with the franchise (I wasn't), then I hear that this installment does not differ very much from Tropico 3 and you might want to treat it, price-wise, more like DLC.  Let me stress that this game is funny. It is riddled with top-notch humour throughout, and the mostly stellar voice acting does justice to the character-specific jokes. I'd even go far enough to call this a good introductory game to the city-building strategy genre: you can easily take your time at every turn, and even if you find the mechanics hard to get around to, the constant jokes should provide a good incentive to stick around.

There's an easy way to recommend this game: did you like Tropico 3? If yes, you'll dig this, if not, pass. This game's called Tropico 4 but it's nominally an expansion pack to Tropico 3, though a large one at that. Tropico is a nation-building game in the vein of the Anno series, though not nearly as in-depth and with a sense of humor. It features a few new buildings and edicts and some new mechanics, as well as an entirely new campaign. A few of the added structures make things a little easier- like the salt mine, a mine that never runs out, and the chemical plant, a factory that requires no input. The mechanic improvements serve to streamline the gameplay and the added buildings are interesting. The campaign is quite good and about 40 hours long, a decent amount of play can be had. There is of course a sandbox mode if all you wish to build is an island. I very much recommend this game if you enjoy city or nation building games.

Tropico lets you be the dictator of your own Tropical Island. As 'el Presidente' of Tropico your will is law. Like in other city-building games you get to choose what to build, what demands shall be met, but also how to deal with unrest. The main differences with a game like Anno are that: 1) Tropico plays a bit more casual when it comes to usage of space, but does let you create roads more freely and 2) you have to deal with your population, 3) you have to deal with the international super-powers to prevent being invaded. Unique in it's setting combined with a unique sense of humour (that extends to their facebook page, example: 'El Presidente takes his hat off for Kim Jong Un! Congrats to such a neatly organized and executed election. At the moment he's thinking about sending over Penultimo for a little worshop'), I can totally recomend this game.   Tropico 4 looks exactly like the third installment and if you buy the game without the expansion 'Modern Times' there is really no difference. The Tropico 4 in a pack is actually quite worth your money if you enjoy city-building games and or government games.   One MAYOR negative point for this game: it comes with terribly annoying DRM. The game is completely singleplayer, there is no multiplayer element whatsoever. You buy the game here on steam, but you still need a seperate account with Kalypso. You need to log-on to Kalypso everytime you boot the game. There is no reason for this. But I'm sticking with the positive review, because I also hope they drop the DRM someday (please email them about it like I did).  When it comes to maturity of this game, when it comes to violence, repression and persecution this game tops them all. The choices you make lead to rebellions. Members of society decide to leave the city and hide in the woods on the island, pick up an AK and fight you. You need an army to quell them, and this gives some action, some firefights in the game (no strategy element) and 'el Presidente' (your customizable ingame avatar, you can even build a golden statue of your avatar!) will also join these fights.  Your will is law. If you do't like religion, dont build any churches and be prepared for angry people demanding a church. You can even 'oust' an entire faction from the island, taking away that faction's voice in sociey (be prepared for rebellions). And if you really hate religion, you can also build labor camps a jails to 're-educate' them or even let the army kill the members of that faction. Same goes for criminals, imprison them, kill them, let them be, your choice. You can just pull out a list, arange it as you see fit and choose your actions on the individuals on that list. And every gamer has a sadistic mind, even if it's hidden away somewhere... and in this game, you can zoom in to streetview level, follow around the individuals whose fate has been chosen and see it take place.  When you first play the game it's quite hard. But once you get the hang of it, it becomes too easy really. It's a great game, but it does have even more potential.  If you had never heard about this game before, like me before Tropico 3, but are interested... try it out. Tropico 5 is coming out in 2014, so there might be a nice sale for part 4 coming!

I have not played Tropico 1 or 2, I started with 3 and loved it. Once again Tropico delivers a fantastic city builder / economic management game and for those of you who have played Tropico 3, you will find that in terms of the interface and the graphics, not a great deal has changed. The graphics are slighty prettier (but then they were pretty good in 3 imho) and there are a couple of tweaks to the interface that might take 30 seconds or so to get used to, but thats about it.  What it does bring however, is more depth in terms of gameplay and a more story orientated campaign to play through. There are a number of new buildings which have been introduced with their own functions, but for me the biggest improvement in the gameplay is the way the scenarios work. When campaign missions are initially presented, it isnt like 3 where you have to hit a specific goal or goals persay, more that in order to reach your goals you will have to fulfill and complete a number of in game missions in order to win the scenario. Along side this are a vast number of other missions that will pop up, which if you complete might award you money, faction respect, foreign power respect etc etc; you get the idea. This makes playing through the campaign (and even doing the sandbox island) a lot more fun.  I have only 2 minor complaints; I wish the stats that you are presented in the almanac could be drilled down into more. I love stats and being able to have a little more depth would be great. The second, is that I miss the radio DJ from Tropico 3 :(   On a final note, I would totally reccomend that anyone buying this (especially if you are coming off the back of Tropico 3) would do well to have a look at one or two of the guides available on steam. This game is fun to learn, by all means! It's an attractive, well-themed, humorously tongue-in-cheek city sim. The radio personalities, the music, and the graphics all contribute to an entertaining experience that will keep you riveted for easily ten maps.  However, once you've got the basics down - about 15 missions into the campaign, if you've bothered - there's really no reward for you to keep playing. Every island follows the exact same pattern, every playthrough is identical. The campaign missions themselves are really pathetic, with a lame plot for each mission stretched over way too many pointless and time-wasting checkpoints. The auto-generated faction and foreign power tasks are predictable and lame as well, and utterly ignorable most of the time.  The biggest challenge in the game comes from street planning - no joke. By the time your economy has matured, the layout of roads on your island is the only thing that can shut you down. If you have too many intersections, say goodbye to ever turning an export profit ever again. No one seems to be sure if these traffic management problems were entirely intentional, or an idea that snowballed into a monstrosity. I'm told the Modern Times expansion's 'Metro' building helps with this, but truly, why bother?  Tropico 4 offers no reward for mastery or sustained interest, but can offer about 20 hours worth of good clean fun. It's worth picking up on sale if nowhere else, but I'd steer clear of the DLC; save yourself a few bucks.

I remember when I played 'Tropico: Mucho Macho Edition' or something like that as a kid on my ghetto ♥♥♥ poor people's computer way back in the day. I had no clue what I was doing and the highlight was unlocking cheats and spamming as many soldiers and rebels as I can and observe the massacre. I loved it.   Now, however, I'm an adult. You know what sucks about being an adult? You need more out of games to really enjoy them, yet you don't have the time to enjoy the lengthy ones that try to do just that, give you a lot of game. You know, this series does a good job meeting half way. It's not your typical strategy game that requires mastering a bunch of skills, it's a simple simulation game where you run an island civilization from third world country to first world. You basically do what you should already be doing as an adult, budgetting, but for fun purposes.  You manage your money to buy things that make you money in the long term. You do your best to satisfy people on the way in order to protect your image and seat as the island leader. All the meanwhile, you have various political factions that have expectations from you, and you cannot satisfy EVERYONE so you gotta pick based on long term self gain rather than personal preference sometimes. You gotta spend money on stuff that actually costs you money and does nothing more than satisfy people's needs or desires.   There is a lot of games of this genre that does that. This series, especially this particular title, does it very well however by using humor and a fun atmosphere to make the game feel so enjoyable. It's hard to explain, but this series is just really special unlike others within the genre that sorta go for the same thing as the typical 'Sim City' clone.   There is some cons, however. I feel you're not really in control of your population to the extent I'd like. Sometimes, there is even bugs that causes the game to create unnecessary building deletes and the likes. There is DLC that ruins some missions, such as the plant gathering prison for people that are sent to prison. Even though they're prisoners, that structure does not count them as prisoners but as farmers. This is terribly frustrating, but it is one of very few extreme flaws with the game.   I could make a huge wish list of what I'd like to see in the game, but I feel like it is unnecessary. Ultimately, I wish there was more options as a successful dictator/ruler. There is a handful ways of making it, such as tourism or mass amount of economical buildings, or farms, etc. I always feel there should be some evil ways to do it. I always just have a massive amount of plantations and a massive amount of bunkers. This is the only way to be a successful 'evil' leader. Enslave the people that refuse to be soldiers and make money off of them. I mean, this is fun but it's so boring and I feel evil can be expanded upon with, perhaps, other consequences that are not game ending.   It's also worth noting these structures I just listed, Bunker and Plantation, are overwhelmingly overpowered. This game isn't pay to win, but those structures definitely make it a lot easier to play. They're both so exploitable, it's sad to see their heart not go into making them balanced.   It's also sad to see that dlc be so expensive. Luckily, I got the complete collection as a discount long ago. In fact, I only owned a handful of DLC from the collection at the time, but they kindly updated my account with their new DLC at the time, meaning I wasn't entitled to some of the DLC they gave me, but they did anyways. I doubt this was intentional, but I just think it's great they didn't attempt to correct that mistake, assuming it was a mistake. Regardless, I feel like most of these dlc's should have been a part of the main game and they could easily have made expansions worth buying instead. The future dlc, or modern times they may have called it (don't remember) is a great example, that's a great one.  The game series also allows map editting. You can basically make your own missions, which gives the player pretty complicated control. You can make virtually every mission you can think of, it's that flexible. You can also check out the maps in their own online thing to download ones made from other players. It's a decent system and I've downloaded maybe twenty maps, but only liked about two of them. I would say that it's a good added touch, but I wish there was some way to have users leave tags and give the ability to search for said tags. I sometimes think certain maps were highly voted for because of reasons that conflicts with my personal play style.  I cannot think of anything else more to say without rambling further. It's a good game for anyone that enjoys this genre. The gameplay is solid, the replay value is great, the flaws are fairly minimal, and the asking price is decent (I'd argue even lower than the game's actual value even despite its age). It has a handful of bugs that are frustrating, but it's good.  9/10  Pros- Good amount of control, far from perfect but still good Gameplay is simple yet there is many complex decisions the player can make The atmosphere is very colorful and enjoyable. The game has a good sense of humor. The economy isn't overwhelmingly complicated to learn. Anyone that is capable of budgeting to save up for a video game can play this. Map editor  Cons- Handful of bugs and balance issues, particularly with the game's dlc. There could be MORE options for sociopaths that basically wants to overwork people. I don't know what else to put here. I really like this game.  9/10

I'm new to the Tropico series but have played other real-time simulation games like SimCity and Caesar (the latter of which appears to be the closest parallel to Tropico in my gaming experience). I'm now eight boards into the campaign and have figured some things out. As other reviewers have pointed out, the game is very difficult to lose, but it can be challenging for a new player to determine why their city isn't growing as fast as they'd hope or why certain problems persist (certain buildings constantly lack for workers, etc.). The truth is that despite the slapstick banana-republic-tinpot-autocrat gloss of the game, this is actually a surprisingly deep simulation, and the game will throw a lot of information at you that is easy to lose sight of but important to keep track of. Build-and-forget does not work. Even the soil quality or climate of parts of the island can change, meaning that a zone that was ideal for farming a particular crop at the start of the game may not stay that way.  The most frustrating thing about the game is traffic management. Most specifically, your tinpot dictator and his (or her) crack team of mad scientists and engineers might be able to build a nuclear program or an airport, but are congenitally incapable of building a four-lane road. (One wonders how the planes land if Tropico's scientific community is so deep in its principled opposition to wide stretches of asphalt or concrete.) There are also occasional graphical glitches and stability issues, but nothing too frequent or catastrophic on my 2008-vintage PC.  A solid title and worth the price, especially on a Steam sale.

There's a large variety of possibilities for you to do on the island, the campaign is engaging and somehow even funnier than the sandbox, and there's character customization too. Which is nice! If, on the other hand, you're too lazy for that, there's plenty of dictatorial types for you to pick from, from Che to Fidel Castro to the Voodoo Pizzaman, who I am 95% confident was a real dictator. Tropico 4 tasks you with building a settlement on an island, gathering resources and maintaining your grasp on the populace.   To advance through each level; of which there are 20, you need to complete a number of tasks to achieve a particular final goal. There's plenty of variety in these missions, and you can see why when you boot up the comprehensive challenge editor. Needless to say, winning levels is more than just gathering so many resources.  It is a bit of a drag how you have to start each mission from the beginning. As such, missions begin with about half an hour of placing down clinics and churches and placating the communists before you can get to the interesting stuff of going through those missions. They won't dissapoint - for example, in one, you have to host the olympics.  You can run your island as a benevolent ruler or a tyrant by enacting laws, denying/permitting elections and executing/arresting your opponents or having a free press.  Recommended.
